newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Strike sidelines 10,000 buses in Sao Paulo.
newsitem.headline: Strike sidelines 10,000 buses in Sao Paulo.

text.p: A strike by bus drivers on Wednesday kept some 10,000 buses off the streets of Brazil's sprawling metropolis, forcing thousands of people to seek other forms of transportation, officials said.
"Only about 13 percent of the city's 11,500 buses are circulating now," a Sao Paulo transport official said.

Although the strike was nearly 90 percent successful, it failed to bring South America's largest city to a halt. Many residents took the subway, hired cabs or crammed into one of the city's vast army of unlicensed mini-vans to get to work.

Union officials said 55,000 bus drivers were taking part in the work stoppage, which began at midnight on Tuesday. The strike was called to demand a higher year-end bonus from the owners of the city's private bus system.
Owners were offering a total of $200 in two payments, while drivers were demanding $600. The union said it would continue the strike if its demands were not met.
